utterances: What does the chief of staff position mean, anyway, for most of us who are following the news?
Is this something that changes government policy?
I mean, Mr. Card has held this job much longer than the average chief of staff.
Does he have a mark on the government?
He has a bit of a mark.
The job has changed under Andy Card.
In previous administrations, the chief of staff had a more powerful and central role in the administration.
Some people would say James Baker sort of ran the country at the beginning of the Reagan administration.
Under President Bush, Andy Card has acted as a kind of manager.
There are a lot of powerful personalities and egos in the Bush orbit, and Card manages things more than plays that central powerful role that maybe chief of staffs had in the past.
And so with Vice President Cheney, Karl Rove and others around the president, the chief of staff has to be kind of again a manager more than the person in the room shouting the loudest.
Well, Mr. Cheney's not going anywhere, and Mr. Rove doesn't appear to be going anywhere, so you wonder, sort, of what exactly Joshua Bolten think's his tasks are going to be.
Well, he is an implementer.
And so, to the extent that the president recognizes there needs to be change inside the organization of the White House, if he puts Bolten in charge of making those changes, they will happen.
This all relies on the president recognizing some need for change.
We're not going to hear much about this at the public level.

They're not going to come out and hold a press conference and say here are all the failures we've had, and here are the changes we're going to make, but if the president recognizes there needs to be change and puts Bolten in charge of the task, he does both have the power and the constitutional capability of going to those powerful people and saying, this is what we're going to do.
And if he's got the president behind him, he'll get it done.
Here's an example of a kind of thing that he would have to decide.
Immigration reform, I mean, this is a very hot topic today in the Senate.
What are you hearing there?
What's going on at the White House?
And does Mr. Bush feel that he's ahead or not at this point?
The food was good?
Yeah.
Yeah, it was kind of amazing to me.
Kind of amazing to me, too.
I ride Amtrak sometimes.
(Soundbite of laughter)

One of the - maybe the central story of the book is you recovering from a dreadful divorce - I'm not sure there's any other kind - and bouncing back home to Freeville at loose ends with your very young daughter, not knowing what to do.
Right.

And I come from this little town full of women, most of them related to me, and so when my daughter was a baby, and my marriage fell apart, at least I had a place to go, and I knew that I must go there.
I really didn't have that many options.

And I went, and I lived in my sister Rachel's(ph) back bedroom, in her tiny, little bungalow, and she displaced my niece, Raley(ph), who was 5 at the time, and I ended up sleeping in this little kid bed.
And I thought ,what has become of my life?
You know, I thought I was on my way to a whole different kind of life.
I lived in London.
It was sort of fancy-pants, if I could say so myself.
Sure, you could say that.
And I wound up back in my hometown, right back where I'd started, a place I had tried to escape from a few times.
But it was there that I really was forced to take another look at my life.
I grabbed my second chance the way I saw my own mother do that after my father left, when I was a kid.
And really using the lessons learned from all of these women, I figured out how to push up my sleeves.
And with their encouragement, I got going.

And moved back to Washington, D.C., where you'd gone to college, but when you got the chance, that image of the second home that you'd always thought about you were going to have, well, you decided to put that home back in Freeville.
Right.
I always knew that I had to have a home in Freeville, and unfortunately for me, the home I found ended up being a character in my life.
It's this cruddy, little house on Main Street with - well, let me just say when I first bought the house, Emily was 5, and I was so excited.
I'd never owned anything, and my whole family showed up, like on purpose by accident.
They were just driving past.
I ended up…
It's a little town, after all.
I know.
So I ended up with this crowd on the porch and I, with great ceremony, put the key in the latch, opened the screen door, and it came off in my hand and fell onto the porch.
And really, that was just the beginning with this house.
But I held onto it, and Emily and I retreated and went there whenever we could.
And we continued to maintain that our hometown was really this little village.

You also write that of course, you were raised by these women in this little town, yet you also say you were raised by your daughter, and I think those things are consistent; it's just we have to remember that being raised is not a process that begins and ends.
Right.
And you know, with Mother's Day coming up, I'm seeing this in my column.
There's some confusion lately about Mother's Day.
People don't really know who to celebrate.
For instance, if you're like me, you're a mom.
Do I celebrate my mom?
Does my mom celebrate me?
Like what?
It's become kind of a mess.
But what I like to do on Mother's Day is sort of reflect on all of the mothering I've received from all of these women, and I in turn have, you know, tried to mother my daughter.

And what happened is, Neal, like in the best vaudeville partnerships, one of us had to be the pratfall queen, and the other gets to be the straight man, and in our relationship, Emily seems to be the smart one…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…and the joke is usually on me.
So I don't know why that happened, but I got lucky in the kid department.
Well, let's get some listeners in on this conversation.

Our guest, of course, Amy Dickinson, writer of the syndicated column ""Ask Amy"" for the Chicago Tribune, but more importantly the author of ""The Mighty Queens of Freeville: A Mother, A Daughter, and the Town that Raised Them.
If this is your story in part, give us call, 800-989-8255.
Email talk@npr.org.
And Leanne's(ph) on the line, Leanne calling from Fort Wayne, Indiana.
Well, Amy, I just wanted to thank you because I didn't realize we had so much in common, that I wanted to thank my grandmothers and my mother, who were my role models.
My grandmothers were widows.

My mother was a single mom when I became a teenager and unfortunately, later I became a single mom myself, but just that whole notion of what we learn - sometimes without being directly taught - from these strong women in our lives.
And what - if there was one story you could tell us, Leanne, one incident that made you convinced that this was all going to work out, what was it?
Oh boy.
You kind of caught me off guard with that one.
One story that would say that it was all going to work out?
Mm-hmm.

Well, maybe a trip that my daughter and I made from Bullhead City, Arizona, to Columbia, Missouri, in a U-Haul by ourselves with the car, you know, 24-foot car carrier stashed on behind and all the angels along the way that helped us.
Maybe that told me we were going to make it.
Boy, do I know that story.
I moved from Washington to Chicago when my daughter was 14 and we - you know how when you've packed up all of your possessions, you've got the boxes, they're all labeled and taped…
Oh yes.
(Soundbite of laughter)
…there's usually a vanload leftover that ends up in garbage bags.
And we threw these garbage bags into a U-Haul, and we ended up - we looked like we were headed to the landfill, off to start our new life with our 22-pound cat.
And you know, I feel like most mothers and daughters, certainly if you're going it alone, there's one road trip you will never forget.

Leanne, I wanted to read a passage from Amy's book and see if this resonated with you, too: My daughter has watched me start and lose new careers and optimistically dab on mascara for yet another doomed blind date.

She has caught me blowing fugitive cigarette smoke out the window and seen me wipe away my own tears with a paper towel while sitting defeated at the kitchen table, and we taught each other how to have fun.
...The Central African Republic.
Okay, sorry.
I didn't catch all that, but I know that in our lives, my daughter and I divided things and usually, you know, whatever our strength was we did, you know, that particular thing.

And so before she left home and went off to college and started her own life - and she will be a mother soon herself, here, in a couple of months - you know, it was an interesting partnership that we had, a very productive one.
And sometimes I miss that, although I'm very happy for the life that she lives right now.

Well, one thing about single moms and their children is your kids see you at very, very vulnerable moments, and sometimes - I know I did my very best to shield my daughter from what I call the sausage factory of my dating life.
For instance, you know, there are sometimes when your honest emotions just, you just demonstrate them, and there's no partner or husband to absorb this.
And your kids do see you at very vulnerable times and honestly, I think that can be a good thing.
I agree.

I agree that it can be, but it's - well, your daughter - my daughter was 7 when her father and I divorced, but I think she grew up faster as a result of that experience because she became - I don't mean, you know, a full partner, but she became more of a partner in my life than she would've had things been different, probably, and you know, we've had a strong friendship as a result of that.
Leanne, may we wish you and your daughter and your mom and all the other women in your life happy Mother's Day.
Well thank you so much.
It was a pleasure to have an opportunity to talk with you today.
Okay, Leanne, thanks very much for the phone call.
Our guest today is Amy Dickinson, not giving advice today - at least not directly.
We're talking about ""The Might Queens of Freeville,"" her own story of growing up among extended family.
It's also the title of her memoir.
Up next, Amy's daughter, Emily, joins us, and we'll take more of your calls, 800-989-8255.
You can also send us email: talk@npr.org.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Just after moving back to Freeville, New York, with her daughter and settling into her sister's house, Amy Dickinson writes, geometry no longer described our family.
We used to be a triangle: mommy, daddy, baby.
Now Emily and I were two points connected by a thread.
We used to be a group; now I was part of a couple.
Our lives once had a forward trajectory; now I was blown back into my past.
